title: 110_hr270
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2007" and includes a table of contents. The "Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2007" authorizes appropriations to various government agencies to combat trafficking. The "Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2007" authorizes appropriations for the Interagency Task Force to Monitor and Combat Trafficking, including $5,500,000 for the Secretary of State and $3,000 for the Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking for official reception and representation expenses for fiscal years 2008 through 2010. SEC. 102. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for the protection and assistance of trafficking victims in the United States. $15,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 is authorized. Additionally, $10,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 is authorized for a grant program to develop assistance programs for trafficking victims. Authorization of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 to the Secretary of Health and Human Services for the implementation of this section. SEC. 103. Authorization of appropriations to the Secretary of State. Section 113(c) of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to authorize appropriations of $10,000,000 for each fiscal year 2008 through 2010 to the Secretary of State for bilateral assistance in combating trafficking, including prevention, protection, and prosecution of traffickers. To support combating trafficking, funds are authorized for training law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judiciary on trafficking at International Law Enforcement Academies. Additionally, appropriations are authorized for the preparation of annual country reports on human rights to include required information. Authorization of appropriations to the Attorney General is granted under Section 104. Authorization of appropriations to the Attorney General for victim protection and assistance in the US and training activities for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judiciary on trafficking in persons internationally. Program to reduce trafficking in persons and demand for commercial sex acts in the US. The Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2005 is amended to authorize appropriations for various activities related to combating trafficking in persons. This includes funding for victim protection and assistance, training for law enforcement officers, prosecutors, and judiciary, and programs to reduce trafficking and demand for commercial sex acts. The Attorney General is authorized to receive $25,000,000 annually from 2008 to 2010 for these efforts. SEC. 105 of the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 authorizes appropriations to the President for foreign victim assistance, assistance to foreign countries to meet minimum standards, and research for fiscal years 2008 through 2010. SEC. 106 authorizes $10,000,000 to the Secretary of Labor for fiscal years 2008 through 2010. SEC. 107 authorizes $15,000,000 to the Director of the FBI for the same period to investigate trafficking. SEC. 108 authorizes appropriations to the Secretary of Homeland Security. SEC. 108 authorizes $18,000,000 to the Secretary of Homeland Security for investigations on severe forms of trafficking in persons for fiscal years 2008 through 2010. SEC. 109 authorizes $2,500,000 to the Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development for the same period. SEC. 110 specifies the effective date and rule of construction. SEC. 110 specifies that the amendments made by the title take effect on October 1, 2007, or the date of the enactment of the Act. It also clarifies that the amendments do not impact the availability of funds appropriated under previous Acts. The Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include eligibility of juvenile victims of trafficking for interim assistance under the exclusive authority of the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Attorney General is required to create model legislation for states to define and prohibit acts related to child prostitution and trafficking. This legislation must be disseminated to state officials and posted on the Department of Justice website. The term "State" includes various regions. Additionally, technical and conforming amendments are made. Technical and conforming amendments are made to the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 and the Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2005, changing references from the "Committee on International Relations" to the "Committee on Foreign Affairs".
